review_blob:
This should be billed as an Abbey Quad Style / IPA hybrid. Before you actually taste, Abbey Quad is basically what this beer does. As it pours, sits in the tulip, laces, carbonates, and smells (at fridge temp) its Abbey all day. So much biscuit - also a ton of malt, maybe even a doppel bock sniff or two. Basically no signs yet of IPA OR hops.
Once you let it warm to the right temp and take a sip... yea not so much IPA. 
I actually enjoy this, my second one (had the first 3 nights ago) and would still buy and enjoy under a more accurate heading - but cant seem to find much of what youd come to expect in strong IPAs. Their non-traditional method for the beer explains the shift -
beer_name: Thomas Creek Up the Creek Extreme IPA

review_blob:
So glad to have found this at a local mom & pop - 4 pack, this review for the third one having had one 4 nights ago and one 2 nights ago. Never put much stock in the Nevada but they really came through here. Serious quality. As it sits here in front of me - more of an orange / amber, thin, chunky off-white head, easy-going carbonation. 
Nose, palate, taste, and aftertaste all superb. Very juicy palate, reminds me of Heddy Topper on mouthfeel (although quite different in most other regards). Just so much to appreciate here. Time for my first sip.

After spotting this while up in Maine for the weekend, I grabbed one. When I looked it up, the first review gave me a laugh, so Im still chuckling over the aroma of beggin strips. 
That said, yes, I can see where that may be slightly possible, but for me this is much more reminiscent of my standby doppel from Ayinger. Sure its even sweeter and not quite as balanced, but for who its made by I have to say this isnt bad. 
Firm, somewhat lively carbonation, heavier mouthfeel, plenty of dough and malt all day. I think the nose and color are the strongest qualities here. 
Overall, not too subtle, but absolutely worth a go, especially at $6 for 22oz.

I have been drinking this guy for years, along with La Fin du Monde this became my sub for actual Belgians back when I could get it for about $9 a six pack. 
If I want a decent pillow top I have to put in a little effort on the pour, so that is quite a departure from most true Belgians. Aside from that and a lack of real complexity, this is definitely a solid option. Even at about 12 per pack these days, you cant go wrong now that the price of the real thing is depressingly skyrocketing. The spice on this one is what makes it a notch above the Unibroue for me.

This is quite a sensational offering from Bear. Years ago I got into the Racer 5 and as a result have always considered this a solid brewery. 

My review is on the last bottle of my four pack. This model is a ruby color, akin to an abbey dubbel, great lace, bit heavy on the mouthfeel, tons of sedimentary particles to admire in the light. I refrain from even sipping this guy until 30-40 minutes out of fridge. This brings the aromas and flavor development to really start striding from the moment I taste. Well balanced, but on the sweeter side - as alluded the palate is a bit on the syrup side so that lines up - at 18% rye content you can detect a bit of that extra kick of (hot) spice, but Id love to see what a higher percentage might do, being a fan of distilleries like High West and Whistle Pig. 
For the money these are not to be missed.
beer_name: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob:
This is another top shelf DIPA. The color is a nice burnt copper, lacing is really thick and lasting - so I expected more suds on the palate. Not quite as lively as I expected. The nose is really well-done, see other reviewers with better vocabularies for fuller deScription. The taste has a much better balance than most. Bitterness and sweetness do battle, but whichever is winning from moment to moment is irrelevant because you are enjoying the experience. 
After recently being somewhat letdown by Stoudts and even Boulevards Double Wide, it was nice to have one with such a high recommendation pull through. Well done Port, but please have someone give assistance with your labels. Those JV attempts kept me from trying, thus hoarding your brews for years!

Great color here, love the more amber pour than many of the doubles out there - the head here dissipates a bit more quickly, and the mouthfeel is a bit more viscous. The biggest points here come from aroma and aftertaste - love the citrus burst.

This one is so much fun to try and get hold of - I guess its hard not to let the romanticism enter into the review. But having had it both in and out of can, and having tried many of the other top rated double IPAs, I still have to say this one is on my top three. Something about the aroma / palate / flavor profile makes it incredibly drinkable and all around outstanding.

I agree that there is some kind of quasi-lager thing happening in the nose, perhaps as offensive as rolling rock... BUT this has always been one of my standbys as far as Belgians go. The huge pillowed white head, crazy carbo, undistinguishable alcohol presence - all combine for a solid grab anytime.

2006 Baby. Cellar kept for four years, served cool at 5 oclock on a gorgeous New England spring evening. Poured to a hazy, murky amber glow, with some light tan head that dissipated within a few moments. Something in the nose reminds me of Cellebrator or the Paulaner Dopplebock, sweet with toffee notes and citrus spice. The mouthfeel is a rich thickness of malty majesty, and the aftertaste brings out a fruity warming alcohol. This is quite a treat, a long time in the making, and certainly the best BBC I have ever tried. (A lot by the way : )
Cant wait to try the 07 next year...

Read it and weep: 2000 Vintage. Yep. First year of production for this variety. Picked up in a small but glorious shop in Bruges, made the flight home, and shared with a like-minded buddy. This was a completely unique experience. I have only the 07 and 08 years to compare to. The years had treated this brew quite nicely, it had an almost sour bite that was unexpected, yet went quite nicely to balance things out. Im really glad to have had the chance to try a truly once-in-a-lifetime beer.
beer_name: Gouden Carolus Cuvee Van De Keizer Blauw/Blue

review_blob: First of all, I have no idea how everyone gets their hands on these in the states... I was IN Belgium and most places I looked were out. Luckily, I strolled into Brasserie Cambrinus in Bruges on a whim and there, sitting before me among all the other world favorites... I had my pick of all three varieties. Naturally I went for the king. There isnt much I could say that hasnt already been said by people with far greater palates and vocabularies - but in this tasters opinion, it was worth every bit of hype. I took about half an hour drinking mine, be sure to do the same for yours.

2008 Edition, brought up from the cellar and served cool - Off white head that dissipates. Brown body, a tiny bit watery on the mouthfeel. The aroma and taste are what make this brew. Sweet, balanced, malty majesty. Warms up nicely, smooth. Quite a treat. 750 mL

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Single bottle from Spirit Haus in Amherst, MA. Very deep and dark in the glass, I could immediately sense the classic Aventinus on overdrive when I put my nose in the glass. Sweet and rich. The alcohol is evident in brief moments, but overall hidden quite well. Being a huge fan of the classic, this was a real treat. Fantastic. I will be looking to pick up more of these.

A little disappointed here. Shared a 750mL with a buddy. The aroma was decent, but both the appearance and taste were thin and watery. I have enjoyed better Scotch ales and Belgian fusions. For a fine example of the later, grab the Dobbelin IPA by this same brewery = excellent!

First try at Hope & Olive in Greenfield MA. Didnt know anything about it other than it was a Belgian Ale. The staff didnt have a clue, but what a treat it turned out to be! Almost like a more zesty cousin of La Fin Du Monde, or an extra spicy relative of Duvel. They now carry this at Ryan & Caseys. Grab one now.
